resources.string:
"Your password should have :
 - At least six character
 - At least one number
 - At least one special character
 - No space
The account has been created!!!! All you have to do now is check your email in your inbox.
Welcome to the Cote R calculator application
Click on the screen to motivate yourself

The college performance rating (CRC) is an academic record evaluation method used by most Quebec universities to manage admission to certain programs. Each course has its R rating and all the courses taken give a “general” R rating. It is therefore important to take college studies seriously from the start of the first semester.
THE PASS OR FAILURE OF EACH COURSE IS IMPORTANT
A failure cannot be erased from the academic record and therefore has an impact on the “general” R score used for admission to universities, especially in quota programs.

The analysis of the file by means of the college performance rating requires, for each course, failed or passed failed or passed failed or passed, the calculation of a Z score which makes it possible to express the relative position of a student in a group and the calculation of a correction factor (IFG), which makes it possible to estimate the relative strength of the group compared to that of the other groups. These calculations are carried out at the request of the Conference of Rectors and Principals of Quebec Universities (CREPUQ) by the Ministry of Education of the Ministry of Education, Recreation and Sport for each of the scores listed for Recreation and Sport in the report card, with the exception of the marks of the make-up courses. The formula for calculating the college performance rating (CRC) is as follows: CRC = (Z+IFG+5) x 5*
A RATING THAT POSITIONS THE STUDENT COMPARED WITH THE GROUP AVERAGE

Most achievement ratings for an entire college record fall between 15 and 35, here is a benchmark illustrating this order of magnitude: between 32 and 35 (85% and above) - marks well above average ; between 29.5 and 31.9 (80% to 85%) - marks above average; between 26 and 29.4 (75% to 80%) - marks above the average; between 20 and 25.9 (65% to 75%) - marks in the average.
